awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Trustworthy Scientific Cyberinfrastructure (CTSC) will transform and improve the practice of cybersecurity and hence trustworthiness of NSF scientific cyberinfrastructure. CTSC will provide readily available cybersecurity expertise and services, as well as leadership and coordination across a broad range of NSF scientific cyberinfrastructure projects via a series of engagements with NSF cyberinfrastructure projects and a broader ongoing education, outreach and training effort. 

Intellectual Merit:  CTSC will advance the state of cybersecurity practice across the community by analyzing gaps in cybersecurity technology to provide guidance to researchers and developers, addressing the application of software assessment to complicated cyberinfrastructure software stacks, and fostering broadly the transition of cybersecurity research to practice. Broader Impact: Scientific computing and confidence in its results relies on trustworthy cyberinfrastructure. The CTSC mission is to help provide the trustworthy cyberinfrastructure that science requires across the ecosystem of NSF. CTSC's work will impact science through dozens of cyberinfrastructure projects over the project's lifetime. Additionally, CTSC will perform workforce development in the area of cyberinfrastructure cybersecurity through EOT activities: training, undergraduate curriculum development, and student education.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) funds over $7 billion of research each year. Computers and information systems are critical for the performance and dissemination of that research. Ensuring the resulting science is reproducible and trustworthy means having trustworthy computer and information systems, and cybersecurity plays a key role in ensuring that trust. The Center for Trustworthy Scientific Cyberinfrastructure (CTSC) provided the NSF CI community with cybersecurity leadership, expertise, training, and a forum for sharing cybersecurity experiences and lessons learned. These efforts improved the practice of cybersecurity across the ecosystem of NSF cyberinfrastructure projects and and hence the trustworthiness of the NSF science. CTSC established and made significant progress toward a secure NSF CI community in which each project knows where it fits in a coherent cybersecurity ecosystem; has access to the tools and expertise to enact a cybersecurity program that efficiently supports science; participates in the sharing of experiences and collaboration between projects; and benefits from  services from universities, regional and national networks (e.g., CIC, SURA, Internet2).

CTSC directly engaged with twenty-two NSF projects to aid them with their cybersecurity challenges. These challenges included establishment and review of cybersecurity programs, identity management, and the design and evaluation of software security features. CTSC also re-started the annual NSF Cybersecurity Summits bringing together nearly one hundred members of the NSF CI community each year to receive training, hear from experts from outside the community, build relationships, and share experiences. Over one hundred and eighty individuals, representing over a hundred NSF projects, attended one of the three CTSC-hosted NSF Summits. CTSC training at the Summits and other venues trained nearly 300 CI professionals representing over 60 NSF projects. CTSC impacted a significant number of the 24 NSF Large Facilities through seven long-term engagements, and attendance at the NSF Cybersecurity Summit and training events by 15 facilities. Public reports from each of the Summits served to document its findings.

Through these efforts, CTSC establishing an understanding of the role of cybersecurity in producing trustworthy science and the ongoing need for community leadership in this critical area. Following CTSC’s foundational work, an NSF solicitation called for the creation of an NSF Cybersecurity Center of Excellence.

All CTSC reports, guides and training materials are publicly available at trustedci.org and are permanently archived for the public in the Indiana University Scholarworks system (https://scholarworks.iu.edu/).
